Title: Complex Adaptive Systems
Article:
A complex adaptive system (CAS) is a system that is complex in that it is a dynamic network of interactions, but the behavior of the ensemble may not be predictable according to the behavior of the components. It is adaptive in that the individual and collective behavior mutate and self-organize corresponding to the change-initiating micro-event or collection of events.[1][2][3] It is a "complex macroscopic collection" of relatively "similar and partially connected micro-structures" formed in order to adapt to the changing environment and increase their survivability as a macro-structure.[1][2][4] The Complex Adaptive Systems approach builds on replicator dynamics.[5]

The study of complex adaptive systems, a subset of nonlinear dynamical systems,[6] is an interdisciplinary matter that attempts to blend insights from the natural and social sciences to develop system-level models and insights that allow for heterogeneous agents, phase transition, and emergent behavior.[7]

The term complex adaptive systems, or complexity science, is often used to describe the loosely organized academic field that has grown up around the study of such systems.  Complexity science is not a single theory—it encompasses more than one theoretical framework and is interdisciplinary, seeking the answers to some fundamental questions about living, adaptable, changeable systems. Complex adaptive systems may adopt hard or softer approaches.[8] Hard theories use formal language that is precise, tend to see agents as having tangible properties, and usually see objects in a behavioral system that can be manipulated in some way. Softer theories use natural language and narratives that may be imprecise, and agents are subjects having both tangible and intangible properties. Examples of hard complexity theories include complex adaptive systems (CAS) and viability theory, and a class of softer theory is Viable System Theory. Many of the propositional consideration made in hard theory are also of relevance to softer theory. From here on, interest will now center on CAS.

The study of CAS focuses on complex, emergent and macroscopic properties of the system.[4][9][10] John H. Holland said that CAS "are systems that have a large numbers of components, often called agents, that interact and adapt or learn."[11]

Typical examples of complex adaptive systems include: climate; cities; firms; markets; governments; industries; ecosystems; social networks; power grids; animal swarms; traffic flows; social insect (e.g. ant) colonies;[12] the brain and the immune system; and the cell and the developing embryo. Human social group-based endeavors, such as political parties, communities, geopolitical organizations, war, and terrorist networks are also considered CAS.[12][13][14] The internet and cyberspace—composed, collaborated, and managed by a complex mix of human–computer interactions, is also regarded as a complex adaptive system.[15][16][17] CAS can be hierarchical, but more often exhibit aspects of "self-organization".[18]

The term complex adaptive system was coined in 1968 by sociologist Walter F. Buckley[19][20] who proposed a model of cultural evolution which regards psychological and socio-cultural systems as analogous with biological species.[21] In the modern context, complex adaptive system is sometimes linked to memetics,[22] or proposed as a reformulation of memetics.[23] Michael D. Cohen and Robert Axelrod however argue the approach is not social Darwinism or sociobiology because, even though the concepts of variation, interaction and selection can be applied to modelling 'populations of business strategies', for example, the detailed evolutionary mechanisms are often distinctly unbiological.[24] As such, complex adaptive system is more similar to Richard Dawkins's idea of replicators.[24][25][26]

What distinguishes a complex adaptive system (CAS) from a pure multi-agent system (MAS) is the focus on top-level properties and features like self-similarity, complexity, emergence and self-organization. Theorists define an MAS as a system composed of multiple interacting agents; whereas in CAS, the agents as well as the system are adaptive and the system is self-similar. A CAS is a complex, self-similar  collectivity of interacting, adaptive agents.  Complex adaptive systems feature a high degree of adaptive capacity, giving them resilience in the face of perturbation.

Other important properties include adaptation (or homeostasis), communication, cooperation, specialization, spatial and temporal organization, and reproduction. Such properties can manifest themselves on all levels: cells specialize, adapt and reproduce themselves just like larger organisms do. Communication and cooperation take place on all levels, from the agent- to the system-level. In some cases the forces driving co-operation between agents in such a system can be analyzed using game theory.

Some of the most important characteristics of complex adaptive systems are:[27]

Robert Axelrod & Michael D. Cohen identify a series of key terms from a modeling perspective:[28]

Turner and Baker synthesized the characteristics of complex adaptive systems from the literature and tested these characteristics in the context of creativity and innovation.[29] Each of these eight characteristics had been shown to be present in the creativity and innovative processes:

CAS are occasionally modeled by means of agent-based models and complex network-based models.[34] Agent-based models are developed by means of various methods and tools primarily by means of first identifying the different agents inside the model.[35] Another method of developing models for CAS involves developing complex network models by means of using interaction data of various CAS components.[36]

In 2013 SpringerOpen/BioMed Central launched an online open-access journal on the topic of complex adaptive systems modeling (CASM). Publication of the journal ceased in 2020.[37]

Living organisms are complex adaptive systems. Although complexity is hard to quantify in biology, evolution has produced some remarkably complex organisms.[38] This observation has led to the common misconception of evolution being progressive and leading towards what are viewed as "higher organisms".[39]

If this were generally true, evolution would possess an active trend towards complexity. As shown below, in this type of process the value of the most common amount of complexity would increase over time.[40] Indeed, some artificial life simulations have suggested that the generation of CAS is an inescapable feature of evolution.[41][42]

However, the idea of a general trend towards complexity in evolution can also be explained through a passive process.[40] This involves an increase in variance but the most common value, the mode, does not change. Thus, the maximum level of complexity increases over time, but only as an indirect product of there being more organisms in total. This type of random process is also called a bounded random walk.

In this hypothesis, the apparent trend towards more complex organisms is an illusion resulting from concentrating on the small number of large, very complex organisms that inhabit the right-hand tail of the complexity distribution and ignoring simpler and much more common organisms. This passive model emphasizes that the overwhelming majority of species are microscopic prokaryotes,[43] which comprise about half the world's biomass[44] and constitute the vast majority of Earth's biodiversity.[45] Therefore, simple life remains dominant on Earth, and complex life appears more diverse only because of sampling bias.

If there is a lack of an overall trend towards complexity in biology, this would not preclude the existence of forces driving systems towards complexity in a subset of cases. These minor trends would be balanced by other evolutionary pressures that drive systems towards less complex states.

Summary: The meeting focused on the concept and characteristics of Complex Adaptive Systems (CAS). It was established that CAS are dynamic networks of interactions with unpredictable behaviors, capable of self-organization and adaptation to environmental changes. The interdisciplinary nature of CAS studies, blending natural and social sciences, was highlighted. Key distinctions between CAS and Multi-Agent Systems (MAS) were clarified, emphasizing the adaptive and self-similar properties of CAS. Examples such as climate, cities, ecosystems, and social networks were discussed to illustrate CAS in real-world contexts. The historical context provided by Walter F. Buckley’s coining of the term in 1968 was noted, along with its modern applications linked to memetics. The importance of modeling CAS through agent-based and complex network-based models was underscored. Additionally, the discussion covered the misconception about evolutionary trends towards complexity in biology, explaining that while some organisms become more complex over time due to evolution, simpler life forms remain dominant due to sampling bias. The meeting concluded with an agreement on further exploring the implications of these findings for understanding various systems' resilience and adaptability.

Meeting:
>>Complex Systems Scientist: Good morning, everyone! I hope you're all doing well today. Let's start by briefly going over our meeting objectives and what we aim to achieve.
>>Interdisciplinary Researcher: Morning! It's great to see you all. Let's dive into how we can apply these insights across different fields.
>>Systems Engineer: Absolutely. We should definitely talk about how we can use our findings practically today.
>>Complex Systems Scientist: Excellent point. So, today's focus is on integrating our research findings and ensuring they have practical applications.
>>Interdisciplinary Researcher: Sounds good, I'm excited to see how these insights can be applied across different fields.
>>Systems Engineer: Absolutely. We need to ensure that whatever we discuss can be implemented effectively in real-world scenarios. 
 >>Complex Systems Scientist: Complex adaptive systems (CAS) are fascinating because they're not just about individual components but how they interact collectively. This leads to emergent behaviors that can't be predicted by analyzing parts in isolation.

>>Interdisciplinary Researcher: Absolutely! It's like watching birds change direction seamlessly—no single leader but perfect coordination.

>>Systems Engineer: Right, we see this in engineering too. For example, adaptive traffic signals use real-time data to reduce congestion efficiently.

>>Complex Systems Scientist: And these principles apply across fields—like how ant colonies can teach us about supply chains.

>>Interdisciplinary Researcher: Exactly! Even neurons forming networks can be compared to social networks evolving over time.

>>Systems Engineer: Yes, power grids also adapt based on demand changes using similar principles.

>>Complex Systems Scientist: Speaking of adaptation, city traffic patterns evolve from individual driver decisions but create an overall flow we can optimize for urban planning.

>>Interdisciplinary Researcher: And economic markets fluctuate similarly—each player affects the whole system's balance.

>>Systems Engineer: So true! Designing adaptable systems like smart grids relies on these principles too.

>>Complex Systems Scientist: Given this interdisciplinary approach, how can we leverage CAS principles for global challenges like climate change? 
 >>Interdisciplinary Researcher: One key aspect of CAS is their ability to adapt and self-organize. For instance, cities evolve over time based on countless interactions—leading to emergent properties like traffic patterns.

>>Systems Engineer: Right! And adaptive traffic systems are a great practical application—they adjust signal timings based on real-time conditions instead of following fixed schedules.

>>Complex Systems Scientist: Exactly. It's similar to how our immune system adapts by learning from new pathogens over time.

>>Interdisciplinary Researcher: That's true. Social networks also show this adaptability—information spreads dynamically based on user behavior.

>>Systems Engineer: Speaking of dynamics, smart grids adjust energy distribution based on demand in real-time—another good example of CAS principles at work.

>>Complex Systems Scientist: And don't forget ecosystems—they reorganize themselves when new species are introduced. This kind of resilience through adaptation is fascinating!

>>Interdisciplinary Researcher: Absolutely! And think about how cities bounce back after natural disasters through collective effort and resource reallocation. That’s another example of CAS handling disruptions effectively. 
 >>Complex Systems Scientist: Walter F. Buckley's idea of 'complex adaptive systems' really changed how we look at different fields. It allowed us to frame cultural and psychological systems similarly to biological ones, emphasizing their adaptive and emergent properties. For instance, in modern applications like personalized medicine, treatments adapt based on individual genetic information, much like how an ecosystem adjusts to new species.

>>Systems Engineer: That's a great point! In engineering, we see this with smart grids that adjust energy distribution on the fly using real-time data from various sources. It's similar to how a city's infrastructure adapts to changing traffic patterns to prevent congestion.

>>Interdisciplinary Researcher: Exactly! And speaking of cities, urban planning is another area where these principles come into play—cities adapt like living organisms. When a new public transportation route is introduced, it can change commuting patterns and even influence where people choose to live or work.

>>Complex Systems Scientist: Absolutely. Another modern application is in financial markets. These markets are highly dynamic and adapt continuously to new information, much like ecosystems respond to environmental changes. Algorithmic trading systems adjust their strategies based on real-time data.

>>Interdisciplinary Researcher: You know what else? Education benefits from these principles too. Adaptive learning technologies tailor educational content to individual students' needs and learning styles—it's almost like having a personal tutor that evolves with you.

>>Systems Engineer: And let's not forget cybersecurity! Adaptive security systems learn from new threats and adjust their defenses accordingly—much like an immune system responding to pathogens. This dynamic adaptability ensures resilience against evolving cyber threats.

>>Complex Systems Scientist: Definitely! The application of CAS principles in cybersecurity is quite fascinating indeed.

>>Interdisciplinary Researcher: By the way, healthcare also benefits greatly from these principles. Hospital emergency departments use them to manage patient flow efficiently—kind of like how an ecosystem adapts its resources based on availability.

>>Systems Engineer: That's right! It's amazing how these concepts translate across such diverse fields—from urban planning and finance to education and healthcare—showing just how versatile CAS principles really are. 
 >>Complex Systems Scientist: One of the most powerful tools we have for modeling Complex Adaptive Systems is the agent-based model. These models let us simulate interactions between individual agents, which can lead to emergent behaviors that are often unpredictable and fascinating. For instance, in urban planning, agent-based models can help us understand how traffic patterns evolve based on individual driver behaviors. What other applications do you think could benefit from such detailed simulations?

>>Interdisciplinary Researcher: Agent-based models aren't just for urban planning. They can also be used in healthcare to simulate disease spread or in education to model student interactions and learning outcomes. These models help us see how individual behaviors add up to complex system-wide phenomena.

>>Systems Engineer: Yes, but we need to critically evaluate their practical applications. 

>>Interdisciplinary Researcher: Do you mean by checking real-world data accuracy?

>>Systems Engineer: Exactly! In engineering, these models can optimize supply chain logistics by simulating the behavior of individual components within the system. But it's crucial that the data and assumptions fed into these models are accurate and reflective of real-world conditions; otherwise, our decisions might be based on flawed simulations.

>>Complex Systems Scientist: That's a good point about data accuracy. Another significant approach to modeling Complex Adaptive Systems is through complex network-based models. These focus on interactions and relationships between components, allowing us to analyze how changes in one part of the system can affect the entire network. For example, in epidemiology, understanding how diseases spread through social networks can help develop more effective containment strategies. How do you think these network-based models compare to agent-based models in terms of their practical applications?

>>Interdisciplinary Researcher: Network-based models give us a broader view of relationships between components.

>>Systems Engineer: Just a quick note before you continue—I think it's important we also consider computational limitations when comparing these two types of models.

>>Interdisciplinary Researcher: Absolutely! They offer a different lens compared to agent-based models.

>>Complex Systems Scientist: Right, like seeing an overview compared to focusing on individual details with agent-based models.

>>Systems Engineer: It's like having both perspectives is essential for a complete understanding.

>>Interdisciplinary Researcher: Exactly! Both perspectives are crucial for understanding how systems function as a whole. 
 >>Complex Systems Scientist: You know, it's a common misconception that evolution always leads to more complexity. From a systems perspective, simpler life forms are still dominant because they're efficient and adaptable. For example, while multicellularity allowed for specialization and division of labor in resource-rich environments, it’s not the universal trend.

>>Systems Engineer: Right, simpler life forms show that complexity isn't always the end goal of evolution. In engineering, we see similar trends where simplicity often leads to greater efficiency and robustness. Like in software development, simpler code can be easier to maintain and less prone to errors.

>>Interdisciplinary Researcher: Absolutely! I remember working on a project where we found that simpler algorithms were much easier to implement and maintain. It's fascinating how these trends towards complexity appear across various fields. In sociology, social structures can become more complex as societies grow and interact more. But this doesn't mean simpler forms disappear; they often coexist and adapt.

>>Complex Systems Scientist: Exactly! The persistence of simpler life forms highlights that complexity isn't a universal endpoint in evolution. It's more about adaptability and survival in varying environments. Do you think there are scenarios where complexity is unavoidable for survival?

>>Interdisciplinary Researcher: That's an interesting point! Sometimes in computer science, more complex algorithms are necessary for specific tasks like machine learning or data analysis.

>>Systems Engineer: Yeah! And in advanced robotics, complexity might be necessary to achieve certain functionalities. But even then, we try to keep things as simple as possible because it makes maintenance so much easier.

>>Complex Systems Scientist: Um... right! And if we look at it from a broader perspective, it's clear that evolutionary success is about finding what works best for survival rather than just becoming more complex.

>>Interdisciplinary Researcher: So true! And you know what? It's like how in sociology simpler social structures can coexist with more complex ones. This coexistence allows for a diverse range of strategies to thrive—much like biological systems.

>>Systems Engineer: Exactly! Simpler systems being resilient reminds me of how basic engineering principles often lead to robust solutions. Like when designing circuits—keeping things simple usually means fewer points of failure.

>>Complex Systems Scientist: Indeed! The diversity of strategies seen in nature really underscores the importance of adaptability over sheer complexity. It’s all about finding balance within different environments. 
 >>Interdisciplinary Researcher: You know, it's fascinating how different systems find their own balance. For instance, in urban planning, cities often adapt to new challenges by reconfiguring resources and infrastructure. It's like they self-organize much like an ant colony responding to environmental changes.

>>Systems Engineer: Exactly! Cities are a great example of complex adaptive systems. They constantly adjust their infrastructure and resources to meet new challenges. From an engineering perspective, this adaptability is crucial for resilience. We need real-time data and predictive models to make dynamic adjustments in urban planning.

>>Complex Systems Scientist: That's true. The resilience of these systems lies in their ability to self-organize and adapt after disruptions. Take ecosystems, for example—they bounce back after wildfires or floods by reorganizing themselves. This can teach us a lot about making human-made systems more adaptable.

>>Interdisciplinary Researcher: Speaking of ecosystems, I remember visiting a forest that had been devastated by a wildfire years ago. It was amazing to see how new growth had emerged over time, creating a different but thriving ecosystem.

>>Systems Engineer: Right! And if we apply this principle to urban planning, we could develop flexible infrastructure that can quickly adapt to unexpected events—just like how that forest regenerated itself.

>>Complex Systems Scientist: Absolutely! But here's something interesting—power grids also show this kind of adaptability during outages. They reconfigure themselves to ensure continuity and robustness.

>>Interdisciplinary Researcher: So true! And it’s not just about bouncing back but evolving through disruptions too. Imagine cities with modular infrastructure that adapts to various stressors much like ecosystems do after disturbances.

>>Systems Engineer: Absolutely! By integrating flexibility into our designs—whether it's urban infrastructure or power grids—we can enhance both adaptability and resilience.

>>Complex Systems Scientist: Indeed! But let's not forget that ecosystems don't merely return to their previous state after a disturbance; they often emerge with new species compositions and altered structures that are more robust against future perturbations. This dynamic adaptability is crucial for enhancing the resilience of human-made systems.

>>Interdisciplinary Researcher: Well said! The same principles apply across different fields—by designing adaptable systems we ensure they remain resilient in face of unforeseen challenges. 
 >>Complex Systems Scientist: As we evaluate our options, it's essential to consider the trade-offs between adaptability and stability. A highly adaptable system can respond to unexpected changes efficiently but might require more sophisticated monitoring tools and skilled personnel for maintenance. How do we ensure that our team is equipped to handle these complexities?

>>Systems Engineer: Right, a highly adaptable system might be more responsive but could also demand higher maintenance costs and specialized skills. On the other hand, a more stable system might be easier to manage but less flexible in dynamic environments. So, how do we prioritize these factors based on our current resources and long-term goals?

>>Interdisciplinary Researcher: We need to balance adaptability with stability by considering our team's current capabilities and future training needs. If we opt for a highly adaptable system, we should plan for ongoing training programs.

>>Complex Systems Scientist: Let's list out the key criteria: maintenance complexity, response time, system robustness—

>>Systems Engineer (interrupting): Shouldn't scalability be one of those key criteria too? It's crucial given our growth projections.

>>Complex Systems Scientist: Good point! Yes, scalability should definitely be included. So that's maintenance complexity, response time, system robustness, training requirements—and scalability. How do these factors weigh against each other for each option?

>>Interdisciplinary Researcher: Considering scalability—it seems like we need to prioritize based on our current resources and long-term goals. For instance, if we have limited resources now but expect growth in the future—

>>Systems Engineer (overlapping): Maybe a more stable system with gradual adaptability could be ideal.

>>Interdisciplinary Researcher: Exactly! What do you think?

>>Complex Systems Scientist: We should also consider the scalability of each option. A highly adaptable system might scale more efficiently as our needs grow but could introduce complexities in integration with existing systems. 
 >>Systems Engineer: So, we need to finalize our decision on the system design. Are we all in agreement that scalability should be a key criterion? If so, let's assign specific tasks. I'll look into the technical feasibility. Who can handle integration?

>>Interdisciplinary Researcher: Sure, I can do that. How about we set a deadline for initial evaluations by next Friday?

>>Complex Systems Scientist: Sounds good to me! I'll check how adaptable the system is to future changes.

>>Systems Engineer: Great! And if any issues come up during our evaluations, let's touch base mid-week to address them quickly.

>>Interdisciplinary Researcher: Perfect!

>>Complex Systems Scientist: Agreed. Let's keep communication open as we move forward. 
 >>Interdisciplinary Researcher: We've covered a lot today—scalability, CAS principles' applications... What's next?

>>Systems Engineer: We need actionable steps aligned with what we've discussed. Let's start by planning how to implement adaptive traffic systems and smart grids.

>>Complex Systems Scientist: Agreed, but we also need to ensure these systems can adapt to future changes. How do we keep them resilient?

>>Interdisciplinary Researcher: I think it's crucial that we not only develop a plan but also ensure continuous monitoring. This way, we can adapt our systems in real-time to any unforeseen challenges.

>>Complex Systems Scientist: Continuous monitoring is important, but we should also incorporate predictive analytics to anticipate potential disruptions before they occur. How can we integrate these capabilities into our systems?

>>Systems Engineer: Integrating predictive analytics sounds good; let's ensure our data sources are reliable first.

>>Interdisciplinary Researcher: Exactly! Monitoring and predictive analytics will help us maintain resilience. How about setting up a follow-up meeting to review our progress and make adjustments?

>>Complex Systems Scientist: I agree with most points, but I'm concerned about the feasibility of real-time processing with our current infrastructure.

>>Systems Engineer: Good point. Establishing a robust data governance framework with regular audits would be essential here.

>>Interdisciplinary Researcher: Absolutely! Let’s set up that follow-up meeting for next Wednesday.
